areaDesc.2: Land rises sharply to the north and west.
areaDesc.4: Possible spread of undesirable element from the east and south.
areaDesc.14: A somewhat newer development containing homes of modest size and of varied but pleasing architecture. Plots are small but well cared for. There is no topographical or other barrier between this and the far less desirable area to the east, save a hill.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and wooded terrain.
areaDesc.4: Distance from center of city.
areaDesc.14: This land is largely owned by the Phillip's family whose plant lies in the adjoining industrial area to the north. North of Glenbrook Road, they constructed for themselves several very large and attractive homes. On the land to the south, they have built a number of modern, small and attractive homes which they rent.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and wooded terrain.
areaDesc.3: Convenient to small shopping centers in the Villages of Noroton Heights and Darlen.
areaDesc.4: Character of improvement and lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: This is a sparsely setled section which contain cheaply constructed, small, frame homes; a few of which are of the bungalow type.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and well wooded land.
areaDesc.3: convenient to small shopping area in center of section.
areaDesc.4: None, save lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: This is a somewhat older and sparsely improved section containing a mixture of large and small homes on plots of proportionate size.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and wooded land.
areaDesc.4: Inconvenience of location and lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: This is a slightly older and sparsely settled section in which most of the homes are of moderate size and generally lcoated on proportionate plottages. Open fields separate this section from the hazardous one to the northeast.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and wooded land.
areaDesc.4: Character of occupant and improvement.
areaDesc.14: These are two old sections in the heart of the town which have been given over to the laboring class. While one family dwellings predominate, there are also a number of two and three fmaily.

areaDesc.2: Land is flat along the water's edge and to the north becomes rolling. Most of the terrain is well wooded.
areaDesc.4: Inconvenient to stores and shopping center as well a lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: In general, this is a sparsely settled section; although a few scattered portions are fairly well built up. The majority of the homes are of a fair size, modern and of attractive architecture. Many, particularly those along the Post Road, approach estates in size. Almost all are occupied only during summer months. A wide arterial highway- the Boston Post Road- separates this from the less desirable area to the northest.

areaDesc.2: High, rolling and wooded land.
areaDesc.3: Attractiveness of location, improvement and occupant.
areaDesc.4: None, save lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: This is a small town of greater than the average attraction. This particular section contains, for the most part, dwellings of substantial size and estates - the summer homes of wealthy New Yorkers. There are, however, a few small homes.

areaDesc.2: High, rolling and wooded land.
areaDesc.3: Attractiveness of a small town and containing a small shopping center.
areaDesc.4: Lack of sewers only.
areaDesc.14: This is an older, residential section containing in its center, a small shoppping district. Homes are entirely single family but of varying size and are located on proportionately sized plots.

areaDesc.2: High, rolling land.
areaDesc.3: Attractiveness of development and its convenience of location.
areaDesc.4: Lack of sewers and necessity of traversing undersirable section of the city to reach location.
areaDesc.14: A new and highly restricted residential area built around a golf course. It is partly within the city and partly within the town. Dwellings are of varied but attractive architecture, located on plots of substantial size. Homes range from more modest to extremely large. These latter never appear in the rental market.

areaDesc.2: Rolling land rising to the north.
areaDesc.4: Character of occupant and improvement. Institutional dumping.
areaDesc.14: In this generally densely populated section is a mixture of old and new housing varying from singles to multi-family and all built closely together. the area is now given over to the city's undesirable element. There has been just completed a slum clearance project at Richmond Hill. Institutionally owned properties in this section are being dumped for whatever they will bring.

areaDesc.2: Land rising to the north and wooded in setions.
areaDesc.4: Character of development and ocupants
areaDesc.14: This section contains a number of cheaply constructed dwellings of varying size ranging from bungalows to two-family homes. Those in the south are somewhat newer but those in the north are of fair age. On West Avenue, between West Main Street and Selleck Street, are a few Negros. Also on Ardmore Road.

areaDesc.2: Low, but slightly rolling land.
areaDesc.3: Convenient to center of city and places of employment.
areaDesc.4: Encroachment of business and industry
areaDesc.14: This quite thickly populated section contains a mixture of 1, 2 nd 3 family dwellings, most of which are built closely together and are of substantial age. They serve to house factory workers in the adjoining industrial area. There are a few scattered plants within the section itself. There are a few colored families along the railroad and on Crosby Street.

areaDesc.2: Land generally flat and wooded, particularly in the north.
areaDesc.4: Age and obsolescence of dwellings.

6.a: Singles - a few converted into 2 family

areaDesc.14: This is an old section of the city. Houses are of fair size, generally, though plots are small. Quite a few in the southern portion have been converted into two family homes. Pride of ownership is spotty. There are a few Negros on Franklin Street, Washington Avenue, and Woodside Street.

areaDesc.2: Well wooded land rising to the north and there becoming rolling. The northern portion lies within the town and beyond the city limits.
areaDesc.4: None, save lack of sewers beyond the city limits.
areaDesc.14: Within this area there is a considerable variance in type and size of structures; all being located on plots of proportionate size.

areaDesc.2: Rolling and wooded land.
areaDesc.4: None.
areaDesc.14: This was formerly an area of large, old estates. A number have been broken up for development purposes. Today, this section contains a mixture of old, large estates and small, modern homes on plots of proportionate size. It is, therefore, impossible to arrive at any predominating value or rent. Estates are either owner occupied or closed up; there being no demand for same.

areaDesc.2: Wooded land rising to the north. At least half of this area lies beyond the city limits in the Town of Stamford.
areaDesc.4: None, save lack of sewers beyond the city limits.
areaDesc.14: There is a wide difference in both size of home and property. They range from small dwellings to estates and there is an equal variation in their age. A few of the very large homes have been closed and these represent practically the only vacancies. In the southwest corner there are a few, modern apartments.

areaDesc.2: Slightly rolling land and generall well wooded. All of this area lies beyond the city limits and includes the two small villages of Springdale and Belltown; each having its own small shopping center.
areaDesc.4: Distance from center of city and lack of sewers.
areaDesc.14: The majority of homes and plots are small. Architecture, though somewhat varied, is not overly pleasing. There are also not a few homes which are far less desirable than the average and becuase of this, the area should rate a "low blue".

areaDesc.2: Wooded land rising from the water and river to the west and becoming rolling. The northern and southern portions lie beyond the city limits within the Town of Stamford.
areaDesc.4: Distance from center of city, stores and schools. Lack of sewers beyond city limits.
areaDesc.14: The majority of properties in this area comprise small dwellings located on plots in proportion. There are, however, a few large new homes owned and occupied by some of Stamford's leading citizens but not in sufficient quantity to alter the grading of this section. There is one negro family on Courtland Hill Terrace.

areaDesc.2: Generally flat, low land which rises slightly in the north.
areaDesc.3: In the west, convenience of location and in the east, frontage on Long Island Sound.
areaDesc.4: Character of improvement.
areaDesc.14: In the northwest are found a mixture of old, one to three-family homes. In the southeast, homes are somewhat newer and a number are of the bungalow type. There are a few Negros in the Cove Section.

areaDesc.2: Low, wooded land.
areaDesc.4: Necessity of traversing undesirable sections to reach this area.
areaDesc.14: This is an old, residential section for the most part containing large homes of substanial size and age. Not a few of these are closed up and unoccupied. Because of the desirability of the location, it is safe to assume that, evantually, these old dwellings will be replaced by modern, new homes ultimately changing this to a "first grade" area. High land values should prevent any further decline in desirability.

areaDesc.2: Wooded land rising slightly to the northwest and forming a point in Long Island Sound.
areaDesc.4: Necessity of passing through undesirable sections of the city in order to reach this area.
areaDesc.14: This is a highly desirable and well restricted section of summer homes, which is operated almost as a club. A gate and guard prevent undesirables from even entering the area. Dwellings are of varying size and architecture is pleasing. Plots are largely extensive.

areaDesc.2: Generally low land.
areaDesc.3: Convenient to center of city and places of work.
areaDesc.4: Character of neighborhood and occupant. Institutional dumping.
areaDesc.14: This is an old section of the city which now approximates a slum area. Dwellings are built closely together and vary from singles to multi-family units. Institutionally owned properties in this area are being sold for whatever amounts they will bring.

areaDesc.2: Low, flat land in the east which is higher in the west.
areaDesc.4: Character of improvement and occupant. Eastern portion is subject to floods.
areaDesc.14: This is largely devlopment of cheap, small bungalows which, because of price, has attracted an undesirable element. In the eastern portion, almost all cellars are flooded during periods of high water.

areaDesc.2: Wooded land rising from the water to form a central ridge.
areaDesc.4: Necessity of passing through undesirable setions to reach this area.
areaDesc.14: This is an older section largely devoted to summer homes although some are occupied the year round. Most of the dwellings are of fair size although plots are generally small.

areaDesc.2: Land rises from the water forming a central ridge. Area is well wooded.
areaDesc.3: Attractiveness of lcoation and its improvement, as well as zoning restrictions.
areaDesc.4: Necessity of traversing undesirable sections of the city to reach this area.
areaDesc.14: This is one of the best known summer residential sections in the neighborhood of New York City and has been for a number of years. Dwellings vary from the modest to those of substantial size. Architecture is varied but pleasing. Owing to high land values, plots are not extensive, yet of sufficient size.

areaDesc.2: Flat land extendig out into the Long Island Sound.
areaDesc.3: Zoning restrictions and attractiveness of location.
areaDesc.4: To reach area, necessity of passing through undesirable sections of the city.
areaDesc.14: This is a highly restricted residential area containing summer homes of New York business men. Dwellings vary from the modest to those of considerable size with lots in proportion. Vacant and somewhat swampy land forms a natural barrier between this and the less desirable area to the north.
